bibl.title: Hellenizing Art in Ancient Nubia 300 BC - AD 250 and its Egyptian Models. A Study in "Acculturation".

series.title: Culture and History of the Ancient Near East.

bibl.note: Introduction. The Nubian Scene. - I. Ergamenes, Aktisanes, and the Modern. - II. Reception without Understanding? - III. An Elusive Model: Images of Egypt's Multicultural Identity in the Ptolemaic and Roman Periods. - IV. Early Contacts with Ptolemaic Egypt and the Early Imports. - V. Hellenizing Architecture and Sculpture in Meroe City. - VI. The Great Enclosure at Musawwarat es Sufra. - VII. From Mass-Product to Luxury and Back. - VIII. The Hellenistic Egyptian Style Kiosk at Naqa or "Acculturation" Sidetracked. - IX. Media and Messages. The Autonomy of Nubian "Acculturation". - Indexes.
bibl.seg: Török László, Hellenizing Art in Ancient Nubia 300 BC - AD 250 and its Egyptian Models. A Study in "Acculturation". (Culture and History of the Ancient Near East. 53.)
Leiden - Boston, Brill, 2011, 8°, xxvi-483 pp., tabl., 1 fig., 160 pll. ISBN 978-90-04-21128-5. €161.

Introduction. The Nubian Scene. - I. Ergamenes, Aktisanes, and the Modern. - II. Reception without Understanding? - III. Hellenizing Architecture and Sculpture in Meroe City. - VI. The Great Enclosure at Musawwarat es Sufra. - VII. From Mass-Product to Luxury and Back. - VIII. The Hellenistic Egyptian Style Kiosk at Naqa or "Acculturation" Sidetracked. - IX. Media and Messages. The Autonomy of Nubian "Acculturation". - Indexes.
